title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #174: Euclidean Ramsey Sets**

**Question:** Characterize which finite sets in ℝⁿ are Ramsey.

A set is Ramsey if: for any k-coloring of sufficiently high-dimensional space, a monochromatic congruent copy exists.

**Known:** Ramsey ⟹ Spherical (EGMRSS 1973)
**Conjectured:** Spherical ⟹ Ramsey (Graham), Ramsey ⟺ Subtransitive (LRW)

**STATUS: OPEN** - Characterization unknown.
mathContext: Euclidean Ramsey theory extends combinatorial Ramsey theory to geometry, asking which point configurations must appear monochromatically in colored high-dimensional space.

title: Finite Configuration
content:
**FiniteConfig n:**

A finite configuration in ℝⁿ is simply a finite set of points (a Finset of EuclideanSpace vectors).

The Ramsey question asks which such configurations have the special property that they appear monochromatically in any coloring.

title: Congruent Copy
content:
**IsCongruentCopy:**

A congruent copy of configuration A is its image under an isometry—a distance-preserving map.

This captures 'same shape and size' but possibly rotated, reflected, or translated. The Ramsey property requires finding such copies that are all one color.

title: k-Coloring and Monochromaticity
content:
**Coloring and IsMonochromatic:**

A k-coloring assigns one of k colors to every point in Euclidean space. A set is monochromatic if all its points have the same color.

The Ramsey property requires finding monochromatic copies no matter how the coloring is chosen—an adversarial guarantee.

title: IsRamsey Predicate
content:
**IsRamsey:**

The central definition: A ⊂ ℝⁿ is Ramsey if for any number of colors k, some high enough dimension d guarantees a monochromatic copy.

**Formally:** ∀k ≥ 1, ∃d, ∀χ (k-coloring of ℝᵈ), ∃ monochromatic congruent copy of A.

The dimension d depends on both the configuration A and the number of colors k.

title: Spherical Set
content:
**IsSpherical:**

A set is spherical if all its points lie on the surface of some sphere—equidistant from a common center.

**Examples:** Vertices of regular polygons, simplices, rectangles.
**Non-example:** Four collinear points with unequal spacing.

title: Ramsey Implies Spherical (EGMRSS 1973)
content:
**ramsey_implies_spherical:**

The EGMRSS theorem (1973): Every Ramsey set must be spherical.

**Contrapositive:** To show A is NOT Ramsey, exhibit that A is not spherical.

**Proof idea:** If A is not spherical, construct a distance-based coloring that prevents monochromatic copies.
mathContext: This is the only known NECESSARY condition for being Ramsey. The sufficient direction remains open.

title: Graham's Conjecture
content:
**graham_conjecture:**

Graham conjectures the converse: Every spherical set is Ramsey.

If true, this would completely characterize Ramsey sets as exactly the spherical ones. The conjecture remains **OPEN**.

title: Subtransitive Set (LRW)
content:
**IsSubtransitive:**

A set is subtransitive if it embeds in a set S where rotations act transitively (any point can be rotated to any other while preserving S).

**Intuition:** Sets with 'enough symmetry' should be Ramsey.

**Examples:** Regular polygons are subtransitive (embed in circles).
mathContext: The algebraic structure of rotation groups may be key to understanding Ramsey sets.

title: LRW Conjecture
content:
**lrw_conjecture:**

The Leader-Russell-Walters conjecture (2012): A set is Ramsey if and only if it is subtransitive.

This provides an alternative algebraic characterization to Graham's geometric conjecture. The conjecture remains **OPEN**.

title: Rectangles are Ramsey
content:
**rectangle_is_ramsey:**

The vertices of any k-dimensional rectangle (box) form a Ramsey set.

**Proof method:** Product argument in high dimensions. This was one of the first non-trivial results (EGMRSS 1973).

title: Simplices are Ramsey
content:
**simplex_is_ramsey:**

Every non-degenerate simplex (k+1 affinely independent points) is Ramsey.

Proved by Frankl and Rödl (1990) using partite methods. Covers triangles, tetrahedra, and higher analogs.

title: Trapezoids are Ramsey
content:
**trapezoid_is_ramsey:**

All trapezoids (4 points with two parallel sides) are Ramsey.

Proved by Kříž (1992), extending Ramsey families beyond simplices and rectangles.

title: Regular Polygons are Ramsey
content:
**regular_polygon_is_ramsey:**

All regular polygons and polyhedra are Ramsey.

Kříž (1991) used permutation group methods. Symmetry plays a crucial role.

title: Concrete Examples
content:
**twoPoints, equilateralTriangle, square:**

Concrete Ramsey configurations with explicit coordinates:
- **Two points:** Simplest Ramsey set (pigeonhole argument)
- **Equilateral triangle:** Special simplex case
- **Square:** Special rectangle case

title: Non-Ramsey via Non-Spherical
content:
**not_spherical_not_ramsey and collinearFour:**

The contrapositive of EGMRSS: any non-spherical set cannot be Ramsey.

**Example:** Points 0, 1, 2, 4 on a line cannot lie on a circle (unequal spacing), hence not spherical, hence not Ramsey.

title: The Characterization Question
content:
**erdos_174_question:**

The main open problem: Find a nice property P such that P(A) ⟺ IsRamsey(A).

While we can trivially take P = IsRamsey, the goal is a geometrically meaningful characterization.

**Note:** characterization_exists shows P exists; nice_characterization_open marks the interesting problem as unsolved.

title: Summary: OPEN Problem
content:
**Erdős Problem #174: OPEN**

**Known:**
- Ramsey ⟹ Spherical (EGMRSS 1973)
- Ramsey families: rectangles, simplices, trapezoids, regular polygons

**Conjectured:**
- Graham: Spherical ⟹ Ramsey
- LRW: Subtransitive ⟺ Ramsey

**Why hard:** Cannot be resolved by finite computation—infinite configuration space.
